pullRequest.body:
Add proofs of the First Derivative Test, in max and min forms, using neighborhood filters.
New branch due to merge conflict in the [old](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/bjoernkjoshanssen_firstderivativetest) branch.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [e2886259b0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16802/commits/e2886259b01d0c0972555928d51821402aefdfd6)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Order.OrderClosedExtr`|612|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.Calculus.FirstDerivativeTest`|1669|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ ContinuousOn.union_continuousAt`
`+ isLocalMax_of_deriv`
`+ isLocalMax_of_deriv'`
`+ isLocalMax_of_deriv_Ioo`
`+ isLocalMax_of_mono_anti`
`+ isLocalMax_of_mono_anti'`
`+ isLocalMin_of_anti_mono`
`+ isLocalMin_of_anti_mono'`
`+ isLocalMin_of_deriv`
`+ isLocalMin_of_deriv'`
`+ isLocalMin_of_deriv_Ioo`
`+ nhds_eq_nhdsWithin_sup_nhdsWithin`
`+ nhds_of_Ici_Iic`
`+ punctured_nhds_eq_nhdsWithin_sup_nhdsWithin`
`+ union_mem_nhds_of_mem_nhdsWithin`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
I don't know why github is suggesting me as a review, but I am not very familiar with this part of the library, so I prefer that someone else have a look.

> New branch due to merge conflict in the [old](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/bjoernkjoshanssen_firstderivativetest?rgh-link-date=2024-09-14T20%3A01%3A31Z) branch.

@bjoernkjoshanssen the correct approach to resolving a merge conflict is to merge the current `master` branch into your PR, not to make a new branch.

> > New branch due to merge conflict in the [old](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/bjoernkjoshanssen_firstderivativetest?rgh-link-date=2024-09-14T20%3A01%3A31Z) branch.
> 
> @bjoernkjoshanssen the correct approach to resolving a merge conflict is to merge the current `master` branch into your PR, not to make a new branch.

Ah yes, thanks... I'm not sure how to get git to recognize mergability in this case, given that e.g.`Mathlib.lean` was changed both by my commits and by changes to `master` that I pulled in between.

@PatrickMassot  Thanks a lot, at this point I've done *something* about each of the comments. One thing to consider is whether to keep the four lemmas below and if so where (the file `Mathlib.Order.Interval.Set.Basic` is perhaps too long already?) I'll push a new version so you can see where it stands.
```
/-- Monotonicity of open intervals under removal of `max` at a left endpoint. -/
theorem mem_Ioo_of_mem_Ioo_max_left {R : Type*} [LinearOrder R]
    {b u‚ÇÄ v‚ÇÄ x : R} (hx : x ‚àà Ioo (max u‚ÇÄ v‚ÇÄ) b) :
    x ‚àà Ioo u‚ÇÄ b := by simp_all

/-- Monotonicity of open intervals under removal of `min` at a right endpoint. -/
theorem mem_Ioo_of_mem_Ioo_min_right {R : Type*} [LinearOrder R]
    {b u‚ÇÅ v‚ÇÅ x : R} (hx : x ‚àà Ioo b (min u‚ÇÅ v‚ÇÅ)) :
    x ‚àà Ioo b u‚ÇÅ := by simp_all

/-- The interval inclusion `(a,b] \ {b} ‚äÜ (a,b)`. -/
theorem mem_Ioo_of_mem_Ioc_of_ne {R : Type*} [LinearOrder R]
    {b u‚ÇÄ x : R} (hx : x ‚àà Ioc u‚ÇÄ b) (H : ¬¨x = b) :
    x ‚àà Ioo u‚ÇÄ b := by
    have := hx.2
    simp_all only [mem_Ioc, and_true, mem_Ioo, true_and, gt_iff_lt]
    exact lt_of_le_of_ne this H

/-- The interval inclusion `[a,b) \ {a} ‚äÜ (a,b)`. -/
theorem mem_Ioo_of_mem_Ico_of_ne {R : Type*} [LinearOrder R]
    {b u‚ÇÄ x : R} (hx : x ‚àà Ico u‚ÇÄ b) (H : ¬¨x = u‚ÇÄ) :
    x ‚àà Ioo u‚ÇÄ b := by
    have := hx.2
    simp_all only [mem_Ico, and_true, mem_Ioo, gt_iff_lt]
    exact lt_of_le_of_ne hx fun a ‚Ü¶ H (id (Eq.symm a))
```

> Just a few more comments about the names of the lemmas.
> 
> If you feel like it, you can also add `IsLocalMin` variants for the remaining lemmas in `FirstDerivativeTest`. But this PR has dragged along for quite long enough, so I'm also happy to merge this without that.
> 
> Other than that it looks good. Thanks for incorporating all our comments!

Thanks, I added minima versions and made the other changes you suggested.

Thanks a lot!

bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11489417682/job/31978169300)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11489901833/job/31979570446)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11489901833/job/31979570615)
Thanks, reviewers, for your patience. üôè
I also reviewed the second file. Almost all its content should move.
I looked only at the first file. There is quite a bit of work to do to put lemmas in the correct file and with greater generality or more usable form.
I also reviewed the second file. Almost all its content should move.

Just a few more comments about the names of the lemmas. 

If you feel like it, you can also add `IsLocalMin` variants for the remaining lemmas in `FirstDerivativeTest`. But this PR has dragged along for quite long enough, so I'm also happy to merge this without that.

Other than that it looks good. Thanks for incorporating all our comments!
This list of imports look very suspicious. Please use `#min_imports` at the end of the file to get a meaningful list (and then remove `#min_imports` of course)..
You're right, `min_imports` did it. (I thought that would have been caught by the Continuous Integration scripts but apparently not.)
Please include a link to Wikipedia if you think this reference to Wikipedia is important, or remove the reference.

I'm not sure I would call it important.
What you're saying makes sense so I'm adding a link.
Those name do not follow the naming convention. You can keep the words ‚Äúfirst derivative test‚Äù in the docstring for discoverability, but then give a meaningful name to the lemma.
Got it, makes sense!

This result has nothing to do in this file, and the assumption are almost all irrelevant. Simply removing irrelevant assumptions leads to 
```
theorem deriv_neg_nonneg {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {x} (h‚ÇÄ : deriv f x ‚â§ 0) : 0 ‚â§ deriv (-f) x := by
```
Note in particular how `a` and `b` play no role at all. Also differentiability of `f` plays no role, but this is more subtle. If `f` is not differentiable at `x` then `-f` is also not differentiable at `x` hence `deriv (-f) x` is zero (by definition). 

The proof also looks painful, this may be because of missing lemmas.
Thanks, yes I was able to prove it with the fewer assumptions you mentioned now. Just have to make the new proof nice...

Was able to do it with just one case split:
```
theorem deriv_neg_nonneg {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {x} (h : deriv f x ‚â§ 0) : 0 ‚â§ deriv (-f) x := by
  by_cases hd : DifferentiableAt ‚Ñù (Neg.neg ‚àò f) x
  ¬∑ have : deriv (-f) x = deriv Neg.neg (f x) * deriv f x :=
      deriv.comp _ (DifferentiableAt.neg differentiableAt_id') (differentiableAt_neg_iff.mp hd)
    simp_all
  ¬∑ exact ge_of_eq <| deriv_zero_of_not_differentiableAt hd
```
In the first case, we still need a lemma about `deriv (-f) x = -deriv f x` if it is not already in the library. In the second you can compress slightly using `Eq.ge` and dot notation.

1st case: Yes, it's in the library as `deriv.neg`. Using that  found it easier to dispense with these lemmas altogether since I can replace their use with one-liners:
```
      (fun x hx => deriv.neg (f := f) ‚ñ∏ Left.nonneg_neg_iff.mpr ( h‚ÇÄ x hx))
      (fun x hx => deriv.neg (f := f) ‚ñ∏ Left.neg_nonpos_iff.mpr ( h‚ÇÅ x hx))
```

Those lines look like we are missing some lemma. Maybe something like
```lean
lemma ContinuousOn.union_continuousAt 
    {X Y : Type*} [TopologicalSpace X] [TopologicalSpace Y] 
    {s t : Set X} {f : X ‚Üí Y} (s_op : IsOpen s) 
    (hs : ContinuousOn f s) (ht : ‚àÄ x ‚àà t, ContinuousAt f x) : 
    ContinuousOn f (s ‚à™ t)
```
would help? It probably won‚Äôt make the proof shorter, but it would make it more discoverable.
Yes! I was able to make that work exactly as you stated it.
You can use named arguments here. Remove the @ sign and use `(f := -f)`.
Nice.
Those two lines are a clear red flag that either a lemma is missing or the lemma is there but you missed it. There should be lemmas relating `IsLocalMin`/`IsLocalMax` for `f` and `-f`.
Indeed, `exact (neg_neg f) ‚ñ∏ IsLocalMax.neg Q` does it.

In those three lines you are fighting against Mathlib. I think this fight is right, so you should make it a pair of lemmas, starting with
```lean
lemma Filter.Eventually.exists_lt_forall_Ioo {Œ± : Type*} [TopologicalSpace Œ±] [LinearOrder Œ±] 
    [OrderTopology Œ±] [NoMinOrder Œ±] {a : Œ±} {p : Œ± ‚Üí Prop} (h : ‚àÄ·∂† x in ùìù[<] a, p x) : 
    ‚àÉ l < a, ‚àÄ x ‚àà Ioo l a, p x := 
  mem_nhdsWithin_Iio_iff_exists_Ioo_subset.1 h
```
next to `mem_nhdsWithin_Iio_iff_exists_Ioo_subset`, and the same with the other one. Then you can write `  obtain ‚ü®u‚ÇÄ, hu‚ÇÄ, diff_u‚ÇÄ‚ü© := hd‚ÇÄ.exists_lt_forall_Ioo`

I was able to make that work, at the cost of adding
`change Ioo u‚ÇÄ b ‚äÜ {x | DifferentiableAt ‚Ñù f x} at diff_u‚ÇÄ`

Do you know you can use `obtain ‚ü®u‚ÇÄ, hu‚ÇÄ, diff_u‚ÇÄ : Ioo u‚ÇÄ b ‚äÜ {x | DifferentiableAt ‚Ñù f x}‚ü© :=` instead of adding a `change` line? I am not saying this is necessarily the best thing to do here, I would have to see the new code to know.
Oh, that makes sense and I do think it's an improvement.
Why don‚Äôt you fully destructure the result here? Why keeping `hu‚ÇÄ` as a conjunction? See the suggestion above where I separate the two components.
OK done (haven't quite gotten into the habit of doing that).
Aren‚Äôt you repeating proofs from earlier lemmas? It means those proofs should be extracted as lemmas.
I'm not sure which earlier lemmas that would be in this case.
`aesop` should be able to help with all those side goals.
OK I got some of them shortened using `aesop`

Why are you suddenly not using notations for `nhdsWithin`? And why are those restricted to neighborhoods of zero? And this has nothing to do in this file. 

Please put
```lean
/-- If a set `P` contains left and right neighborhoods of a point `x` in a linearly ordered
topological space then `P` contains a punctured neighborhood. -/
lemma nhdsWithin_punctured_of_Iio_Ioi {X : Type*} [LinearOrder X] [TopologicalSpace X] 
    {P : Set X} {x : X} (hl : P ‚àà ùìù[<] x) (hr : P ‚àà ùìù[>] x) : P ‚àà ùìù[‚â†] x := by
  rw [‚Üê Iio_union_Ioi, nhdsWithin_union]
  exact Filter.mem_sup.mpr ‚ü®hl, hr‚ü©
```
in some relevant file (not the first derivate test file) after checking it does not exist. This lemma is not even used in your PR!
I'm really not sure where to put it (if anywhere) --- maybe I'll just remove it and it can be a separate PR when someone determines where.
I would try to put it next to `nhdsWithin_union` if this works.
OK I put it there. It's then one of two occurrences of `LinearOrder` in that file `ContinuousOn.lean`.
This is `  nhds_left'_le_nhds_ne b h`, no need for a new lemma.
Thanks, fixed.
Same, this is redundant.
Thanks, fixed.
Same remark.
Fixed, too.
You can use named arguments to avoid Morse code.
Thanks, that's useful.
There is no reason at all to explicitly display those universe variables. Please remove them and use `{Œ± : Type*}` everywhere.
Sure (I only used them because they are already in Mathlib in some similar lemmas).
This has nothing to do here, please move it next to ` mem_nhdsWithin_iff_exists_mem_nhds_inter`.
OK, done.
Same as the previous lemma.
Done
This lemma and the next one should move to the file defining `IsLocalMax`.
OK, I put them in `Topology/Order/LocalExtr.lean`.

Can you formulate this as the supremum of two the `nhdsWithin` filters equals the `nhds` filter (c.f. [nhdsWithin_union](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/ContinuousOn.html#nhdsWithin_union))

Thanks, how about this, which uses `nhdsWithin_union`:
```
theorem union_mem_nhds_of_mem_nhdsWithin {b : Œ±}
    {I‚ÇÅ I‚ÇÇ : Set Œ±} (h : Set.univ = I‚ÇÅ ‚à™ I‚ÇÇ)
    {L : Set Œ±} (hL : L ‚àà nhdsWithin b I‚ÇÅ)
    {R : Set Œ±} (hR : R ‚àà nhdsWithin b I‚ÇÇ) : L ‚à™ R ‚àà nhds b := by
  rw [‚Üê nhdsWithin_univ b, h, nhdsWithin_union]
  exact ‚ü®mem_of_superset hL (by aesop), mem_of_superset hR (by aesop)‚ü©
```
Alternatively, could make the first line of the proof a separate theorem:
```
theorem nhdsWithin_union_univ (b : Œ±)
    {I‚ÇÅ I‚ÇÇ : Set Œ±} (hI : Set.univ = I‚ÇÅ ‚à™ I‚ÇÇ) :
    nhds b = nhdsWithin b I‚ÇÅ ‚äî nhdsWithin b I‚ÇÇ := by
  rw [‚Üê nhdsWithin_univ b, hI, nhdsWithin_union]
```
idem
Done

This is a somewhat arbitrary lemma, because modulo the distinction between ContinuousOn/ContinuousAt, this is basically just `(‚àÄ x ‚àà s ‚à™ t, _) ‚Üî (‚àÄ x ‚àà s, _) ‚àß (‚àÄ x ‚àà t, _)`. But maybe it's fine.
Alternatively, you could also characterize continuity on `Ioc` as equivalent to continuity on `Ioo` + `ContinuousWithinAt` the endpoint. That might be nicer (but you need a separate lemma for `Ico`).
For what it's worth this lemma was suggested by another reviewer, I don't have a strong opinion.
Can this be proven from `isLocalMax_of_mono_anti'`?

Yes! And I guess that's better since the proof doesn't involve any tactics work, it's just
`isLocalMax_of_mono_anti' (Ioc_mem_nhdsWithin_Iic' g‚ÇÄ) (Ico_mem_nhdsWithin_Ici' g‚ÇÅ) h‚ÇÄ h‚ÇÅ`

```suggestion
    (hd‚ÇÄ : DifferentiableOn ‚Ñù f (Ioo a b))
```
Please abbreviate names using the open namespaces
Done, thanks.
Please use dot notation, i.e. something like `hd‚ÇÄ.continuousOn.union_continuousAt (isOpen_Ioo (a := a) (b := b)) (by simp_all)`
That is a brilliant pattern... I did not know.

Lemmas like this should probably not exist. You can use [Set.Ioc_diff_right](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Interval/Set/Basic.html#Set.Ioc_diff_right) to get this quickly.
Similar for the other ones, e.g. by using [Set.Ioo_subset_Ioo_left](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Interval/Set/Basic.html#Set.Ioo_subset_Ioo_left)

OK, I removed that one and the similar one.
As for the ones with max and min (`mem_Ioo_of_mem_Ioo_max_left`), it seems that there is a tension with not-repeating-oneself in proofs, and with golfing. If I remove that those then the proof that uses them will be longer and also more repetitive... I'm not sure how to reconcile those concerns.
just use the existing lemmas and remove these
OK done (although it removes an opportunity to use dot notation).

In Mathlib we often declare aliases for single implications of bi-implications, especially if it enables dot notation.
That is perfectly fine, and the syntax is `alias ‚ü®forward_name, backwards_name‚ü© := existing_decl` (either name can be `_` to not generate that lemma). Feel free to add that, but it must occur directly after `mem_nhdsWithin_Ioi_iff_exists_Ioo_subset`.
Ah okay, I think I'll refrain for now in order to not complicate things.

I think this result more easily derivable from `localMax_of_deriv_Ioo`. Also, use `Filter.Eventually.and` first to conclude `‚àÄ·∂† x in ùìù[<] b, DifferentiableAt ‚Ñù f x ‚àß 0 ‚â§ deriv f x` and simplify the argument.
I'm not sure how, do you mean something like use `rw [Filter.Eventually, mem_nhdsWithin] at hd‚ÇÄ` and then go from there to get `Ioo`?

Use [nhdsWithin_Iio_basis'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Order/LeftRightNhds.html#nhdsWithin_Iio_basis') + [Filter.HasBasis.eventually_iff](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Filter/Bases.html#Filter.HasBasis.eventually_iff)
Oh, that's very nice and it removes the need for some of the lemmas. So I've removed them in the new version.

```suggestion
lemma isLocalMax_of_deriv_Ioo {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {a b c : ‚Ñù} (g‚ÇÄ : a < b) (g‚ÇÅ : b < c)
```
please also change below

```suggestion
theorem nhds_eq_nhdsWithin_sup_nhdsWithin (b : Œ±) {I‚ÇÅ I‚ÇÇ : Set Œ±} (hI : Set.univ = I‚ÇÅ ‚à™ I‚ÇÇ) :
```
or similar

```suggestion
lemma punctured_nhds_eq_nhdsWithin_sup_nhdsWithin [LinearOrder Œ±] {x : Œ±} : ùìù[‚â†] x = ùìù[<] x ‚äî ùìù[>] x := by
```
I'm surprised that `punctured_nhds` already has precedence in Mathlib. We should probably decide what we're calling `ùìù[‚â†]` and similar uniformly at some point (I also see `nhdsWithin_complement_singleton`, which is very long)
Maybe it should be called `nhds_ne`? I don't know.
Yes, that name (and similar ones) sound good. But let's go with precedence here, so that we can uniformly change at a later date.
If you're not using this, please remove, since it's so similar to the previous lemma.
Don't forget dot notation. This can be `(nhdsWithin_Iio_basis' ‚ü®b - 1, sub_one_lt b‚ü©).eventually_iff.mp <| hd‚ÇÄ.and h‚ÇÄ` (while you're still editing)

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: add First Derivative Test from calculus

<details>

I don't know why github is suggesting me as a review, but I am not very familiar with this part of the library, so I prefer that someone else have a look.

> New branch due to merge conflict in the [old](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/bjoernkjoshanssen_firstderivativetest?rgh-link-date=2024-09-14T20%3A01%3A31Z) branch.

@bjoernkjoshanssen the correct approach to resolving a merge conflict is to merge the current `master` branch into your PR, not to make a new branch.

> > New branch due to merge conflict in the [old](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/bjoernkjoshanssen_firstderivativetest?rgh-link-date=2024-09-14T20%3A01%3A31Z) branch.
> 
> @bjoernkjoshanssen the correct approach to resolving a merge conflict is to merge the current `master` branch into your PR, not to make a new branch.

Ah yes, thanks... I'm not sure how to get git to recognize mergability in this case, given that e.g.`Mathlib.lean` was changed both by my commits and by changes to `master` that I pulled in between.
I looked only at the first file. There is quite a bit of work to do to put lemmas in the correct file and with greater generality or more usable form.
I also reviewed the second file. Almost all its content should move.

@PatrickMassot  Thanks a lot, at this point I've done *something* about each of the comments. One thing to consider is whether to keep the four lemmas below and if so where (the file `Mathlib.Order.Interval.Set.Basic` is perhaps too long already?) I'll push a new version so you can see where it stands.
```
/-- Monotonicity of open intervals under removal of `max` at a left endpoint. -/
theorem mem_Ioo_of_mem_Ioo_max_left {R : Type*} [LinearOrder R]
    {b u‚ÇÄ v‚ÇÄ x : R} (hx : x ‚àà Ioo (max u‚ÇÄ v‚ÇÄ) b) :
    x ‚àà Ioo u‚ÇÄ b := by simp_all

/-- Monotonicity of open intervals under removal of `min` at a right endpoint. -/
theorem mem_Ioo_of_mem_Ioo_min_right {R : Type*} [LinearOrder R]
    {b u‚ÇÅ v‚ÇÅ x : R} (hx : x ‚àà Ioo b (min u‚ÇÅ v‚ÇÅ)) :
    x ‚àà Ioo b u‚ÇÅ := by simp_all

/-- The interval inclusion `(a,b] \ {b} ‚äÜ (a,b)`. -/
theorem mem_Ioo_of_mem_Ioc_of_ne {R : Type*} [LinearOrder R]
    {b u‚ÇÄ x : R} (hx : x ‚àà Ioc u‚ÇÄ b) (H : ¬¨x = b) :
    x ‚àà Ioo u‚ÇÄ b := by
    have := hx.2
    simp_all only [mem_Ioc, and_true, mem_Ioo, true_and, gt_iff_lt]
    exact lt_of_le_of_ne this H

/-- The interval inclusion `[a,b) \ {a} ‚äÜ (a,b)`. -/
theorem mem_Ioo_of_mem_Ico_of_ne {R : Type*} [LinearOrder R]
    {b u‚ÇÄ x : R} (hx : x ‚àà Ico u‚ÇÄ b) (H : ¬¨x = u‚ÇÄ) :
    x ‚àà Ioo u‚ÇÄ b := by
    have := hx.2
    simp_all only [mem_Ico, and_true, mem_Ioo, gt_iff_lt]
    exact lt_of_le_of_ne hx fun a ‚Ü¶ H (id (Eq.symm a))
```

Just a few more comments about the names of the lemmas. 

If you feel like it, you can also add `IsLocalMin` variants for the remaining lemmas in `FirstDerivativeTest`. But this PR has dragged along for quite long enough, so I'm also happy to merge this without that.

Other than that it looks good. Thanks for incorporating all our comments!
